did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult Special Collections & Archives staff.
did.abstract: Four generations of Atwaters and their spouses are represented in the family papers: William Warren Atwater (1814-1874), Wilbur Olin Atwater (1844-1907), Helen Woodard Atwater (1876-1947), Charles Woodard Atwater (1885-1946), Catherine Merriam Atwater (1913-2008), Charles Woodard Atwater, Jr. (1920-2002). The Atwaters are associated mostly with Middletown, Connecticut and Plandrom, New York. The papers contain correspondence, photographs, financial and estate papers, research and student notes, and other materials. The papers include family correspondence about family and home matters, travel and visitors; college and social life; and career and professional activities. Wilbur Olin Atwater's letters describe his work and travels in Washington, D.C., Europe, Russia, and Cuba. Helen Atwater's materials include her household and personal finances, and letters from a colleague about war-time and post-war Holland. Some of her correspondence addresses her work in the federal Department of Home Economics. Charles' letters to Helen offer her occasional investment and banking advice. Correspondence between Catherine Atwater Galbraith and her brother Robert discuss family matters including their brother Charles' mental health, condition, and care.

Atwater Family Papers contain correspondence, photographs, financial and estate papers, research and student notes, and other materials from four generations of the family. The papers include family correspondence about family and home matters, travel and visitors, letters from college include commentary on classes, lectures, concerts, and social life, and career and professional activities. Wilbur Olin Atwater's documents include study notes and some college lab notebooks, materials from his research travels in Europe, Russia, and Cuba as well as letters describing his work and travels. His daughter Helen's materials include her household and personal finances, and letters from a colleague about war-time and post-war Holland. Some of her correspondence addresses her work in the federal Department of Home Economics. Wilbur's son Charles' letters to Helen offer her occasional investment and banking advice, noting in 1932 "it is anti-social to horde money at this stage." Correspondence between Catherine Atwater Galbraith and her brother Robert discuss family matters including their brother's mental health, condition, and care. Charles letters describe his work as a farm hand prior to college and during vacations, his service experience as Pharmacist's Mate, and his deepening interest in foreign policy immediately following his military service.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: Copyright for official University records is held by Wesleyan University; all other copyright is retained by the authors of items in these papers, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Atwater Family Papers, Collection 2008-36, Special Collections & Archives, Olin Library, Wesleyan University, Middletown CT.

acqinfo.head: Acquisitions Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of the estate of Catherine Merriam Atwater Galbraith via J. Alan Galbraith executor, in December 2008 and January 2009 (accessions 2008-35 and 2009-01).

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Andrea Benefiel, Val Gillespie, Anne Ostendarp, and Patty Bodak Stark

bioghist.head: Biographical and Historical Note
bioghist.p: William Warren Atwater (1814-1874) was the son of Thomas Atwater and Betsy Boyden Atwater. He was a minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church and temperance advocate in New York and New England. He became librarian of Yale Law School in New Haven, Connecticut in 1872. He married Eliza Barnes and they had two children, Wilbur Olin (1844-1907) and Florence Amelia (b. May 29, 1852).

Wilbur Olin Atwater (1844-1907) was the son of William Warren Atwater. He graduated Wesleyan with the Class of 1865, and earned a Ph.D. in agricultural chemistry from Yale in 1869. He taught at the University of Tennessee, Maine State College, and then Wesleyan University from 1873 to 1907. Atwater was the director of the first American agricultural experiment station, in Middletown, CT, and was later appointed chief of the Office of Experiment Stations in Washington, D.C. (1888-1891). His work in calorimetric study was well known; he researched and published extensively in physiological chemistry and agricultural chemistry. He married Marcia Woodard in 1874. They had two children: Helen Woodard Atwater and Charles Woodard Atwater.

Marcia Woodard Atwater (1851-1932) was the daughter of Abram Woodard of Bangor, Maine, and sibling of Charles and Sarah. She married Wilbur Olin Atwater; they had two children Helen and Charles. Mrs. Atwater lived in Washington, D.C. from 1914 to 1929, and returned to Middletown, Connecticut.

Helen Woodard Atwater (1876-1947), was the daughter of Marcia Woodard Atwater and Wilbur Olin Atwater. She graduated Smith College in 1897. She became an editorial assistant to her father and in 1909 went to work for the Office of Home Economics in the Department of Agriculture as a science staff member. From 1923 to 1941 she was editor of the American Home Economics Association's The Journal of Home Economics, expanding the magazine's reach to scientific and education audiences. She was a member of the Women's Joint Congressional Committee and represented the American Home Economics Association at international conferences. She was a member of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Helen died in Washington in 1947.

Charles Woodard Atwater (1885-1946) was the son of Wilbur Olin Atwater and Marcia Woodard Atwater. Charles attended Philips Exeter Academy, graduated Wesleyan with the Class of 1906, and went on to Harvard to earn a law degree. He moved to New York in 1910, and later established his own law firm, Atwater and Clarke. He served as Consul General for Siam (Thailand). He married Alice Caroline Merriam in 1911. They had three children: Catherine Merriam Atwater (1913-2008), Robert Merriam Atwater (b.1916), and Charles Woodard Atwater, Jr. (1920-2002).

Alice Caroline Merriam Atwater (d.1950) was the daughter of Joseph and Abbie Wilson Merriam of Middletown, Connecticut. She had two siblings, Robert and Helen. She attended Smith College from 1905 to 1907. She married Charles Atwater in October 1911. They had three children.

Catherine Merriam Atwater (1913-2008) was the daughter of Alice Caroline Merriam Atwater and Charles Woodard Atwater. She graduated Smith College with the Class of 1934 and studied at Radcliffe, earning a master's degree in 1937. She married the economist John Kenneth Galbraith in 1937. They had four sons: J. Alan, Douglas, Peter W., and James K. She was a writer.

Charles Woodard Atwater, Jr. (1920-2002) was the son of Alice Caroline Merriam Atwater and Charles Woodard Atwater. He earned a B.S. in Agronomy from Cornell University in 1942, served in the Coast Guard during World War II, experienced mental illness resulting in hospitalizations at the Veterans Administration hospitals, and lived in Tyngsboro, Massachusetts.

arrangement.head: Collection Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Atwater Family Papers are arranged in 13 series by family member and material form.

scopecontent.p: Includes his handwritten six-page biography, and anonymous threats made in response to his work towards the "overthrow of rum traffic" in northern Vermont.

did.unittitle: Vermont Directory and Commercial Almanac by W.W. Atwater, 1855
State Appraisers' Warrant and Report, 1878 Aug 29
An Almanack, for the Year of Christian Era by Abraham Weatherwise, 1788

scopecontent.p: Includes his correspondence and personal papers. Atwater's letters to his future wife include commentary on his classes, lectures and concerts he attended. He records his observations of people he meets in Washington, D.C. and abroad including his introduction to Leon Trotsky (1897). The series includes letters to his children. The series also contains some personal papers from his days at Wesleyan, a diary of study notes and lab notebooks, and correspondence and other materials documenting his travels in Brussels, Germany, Switzerland, Italy, Russia, and Cuba. His letters sometimes mention plans for the Chicago World's Fair (1893) and the Bruxelles Exposition Universelle.

scopecontent.p: Contains Marcia's correspondence with her husband and children and with her father, Abram Woodard, her sister, Sarah Woodard, and brother, Charles Woodard. There is small amount of correspondence with others. She writes of family matters, her and her family's travel, visitors, and house matters. The personal papers include financial and estate documents and documents regarding the care of cousin Frederick Adams and the guardianship of Arthur Spatcher.

scopecontent.p: Contains Helen's correspondence with her parents and her brother Charles. A modest amount of correspondence describes a possible move of the Home Economics department from the Department of Agriculture to the Bureau of Standards. There are some letters from "Willie" Kits van Warren describing war-time and post-war experiences in Haarlem, Holland. Also in this series is some personal correspondence, financial and estate papers including her mother's trust fund, household accounts, and tax returns.

scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence between Charles and Alice before their marriage. There is also correspondence between Charles and his sister, Helen Woodard Atwater, his parents, and friends. He writes to his future wife about college life at Wesleyan University, and a "machine ride" (car ride) in 1907. At a later period he writes about family activities and sailing. There are letters to his sister with occasional investment and banking advice, and his concern for the pending departure from the gold standard, noting in 1932 "it is anti-social to horde money at this stage."

Series VI. Alice Caroline Merriam Atwater, 1905-1950,

scopecontent.p: Contains letters from Alice Merriam to Charles Atwater, most written before their marriage. She describes her social life at Smith College and then in Middletown. There is a small amount of correspondence with others.

did.unittitle: Alice Caroline Merriam - Charles Woodard Atwater, 1905 Oct-Dec
Nassau County, Office of Civilian Protection identification card, Undated
Funeral program for Alice Caroline Merriam Atwater, 1950 May
Series VII. Catherine Merriam Atwater Galbraith, 1940-1994,

scopecontent.p: Contains mostly correspondence between Catherine, sometimes "Kitty", and her brother Robert. Catherine's letters to her brother, Charles Woodard Atwater, Jr. are in Series VIII. There is some correspondence in this series relating to their brother's care and condition, settling their mother's estate, the challenges of growing children and later challenges of caring for a disabled spouse. The series also includes Catherine's articles, correspondence, and research notes on her family history of William Warren Atwater and Wilbur Olin Atwater.

scopecontent.p: Contains his correspondence and papers. Charles' letters describe his work as a farm hand prior to college and during vacations, his service experience as Pharmacist's Mate, and his deepening interest in foreign policy immediately following his military service. Most of the incoming letters from family members have news of children, travel, and house; a small portion touches on his mental health and care. His sister's letters to aunts or cousins are located in this series as enclosures with their letters to Charles. More family correspondence concerning his health and care is found in Series VII in letters between his siblings Catherine Atwater Galbraith and Robert Atwater. The correspondence is arranged chronologically, the personal papers are arranged alphabetically by topic.

did.unittitle: Boy Scouts of America membership card, 1933
Miscellaneous: driver's license, graduate record exam, 1946-1948
Series IX. Atwater family, 1874 and undated,

scopecontent.p: Contains miscellaneous items relating to the Atwater family as a whole (rather than individual family members).

did.unittitle: Print: Race Week at Manhasset Bay, Port Washington, L.I. mounted on wood, undated

scopecontent.p: Contains miscellaneous items relating to the Merriam family as a whole (rather than individual family members). The series includes the postcard collection started by Mrs. Joseph Merriam and added to by family members. The postcards include American and European sites; some cards were sent by family members and friends.

Includes individual portrait photographs of Atwater, Woodard and Merriam family members. There are also some family group portraits and events, as well as few casual photographs of family members and their interests. There are photographs of Wilbur Olin Atwater's laboratory and his annotations on photographs from his 1903 trip to Europe. The photographs are organized by family member; family small group photographs are filed with the older generation (i.e. grandmother and granddaughter filed with the grandmother).

scopecontent.p: Contains printed and published material by, about, or owned by the Atwater family. Their recreational and occupational interests are represented. The series is organized in two loose alphabetical sequences.
